awd_titl_txt: Rationality and Irrationality in Families of Varieties
awd_abstract_narration:
When can we write down all the solutions of a polynomial equation? We seek equations that can be parametrized with rational functions. These are used in mapmaking (stereographic projection), computer graphics, and modeling problems. Indeed, parametrizations are often the most efficient way to render geometric objects as screen images. Mathematicians have developed a rich theory for deciding when such parametrizations are possible. This project will advance this theory.

An algebraic variety is rational if it can be obtained from projective space by a sequence of algebraic modifications. Given a family of smooth complex projective varieties, it is difficult to say which members are rational or irrational, or even to formulate qualitative results about the locus of rational members. The PI will use the technique of decomposition of the diagonal, and related tools from deformation theory, Hodge theory and classical geometry, to shed light on this question. The PI and his collaborators have recently shown that rationality is not a deformation invariant property: There are families of smooth complex projective varieties with both rational and irrational members. Despite examples, like cubic fourfolds, that have been extensively studied, there are no cases where the loci of rational and irrational members have been precisely described. The PI will refine and make effective the decomposition of the diagonal technique to clarify which members of a family are irrational - can they be expressed in Hodge-theoretic terms? At the same time, the PI will advance constructive techniques to exhibit rational and unirational parametrizations with prescribed properties.

por.por_cntn:
Most of the images you see in industrial design and computer graphics are parametrized. For example, a surface in space may be parametrized by

x=f(s,t), y=g(s,t), z=h(s,t)

where f, g, and h are polynomial or rational functions. Such surfaces are said to be rational.  The algebraic formulas allow rapid rendering and easy manipulation.

Given a surface expressed as the zeros of a polynomial equation

S = {P(x,y,z)=0}

can it be parametrized? This would involve finding f, g, and h as above such that

P(f(s,t),g(s,t),h(s,t))=0.

In general, we know that small degree equations have parameterizations but this generally breaks down when the degree is at least four. One cannot parametrize

S = {x4+y4+z4=1}

for example.  

The main focus of this project is to develop criteria for when surfaces and higher-dimensional objects defined by polynomial equations (varieties) admit one-to-one parametrizations. We are especially interested in analyzing classes of equations with a prescribed form, e.g.,

P(x,y,z; t,u,v,w)=0

with P homogeneous quadratic in {x,y,z} and {t,u,v,w} separately. Work with Pirutka and Tschinkel shows that rationality depends in the coefficients of P in a complex way. These are four-dimensional varieties. With Kresch and Tschinkel we obtain similar three-dimensional examples, but parametrized with more variables.

A related question is whether we obtain rationality after specializing coefficients. For example, given a cubic equation in five variables with integer coefficients, can we obtain rational parametrizations after interpreting the coefficients as integers modulo various primes? These problems are related to the behavior of invariants under reduction modulo primes. A recent paper with Frei and V'arilly-Alvarado considers this question.

More recently, I have considered parametrizations of varieties with prescribed symmetries. Here the parametrizations are via matrix representations of the underlying symmetry group. 

My research involves graduate students pursuing their doctoral degrees in mathematics. Their interests cover a wide range of topics: graph theory, geometry over finite fields, abelian varieties and representations, and Cremona transformations. I am also proud to help organize conferences and programs that help early career researchers build collaborative networks and initiate new projects.
